Award.AwardTitle: Zeolite Nanosheet on Hydrogen Permeable Membrane: Coupling Catalysis with Hydrogen Removal in Non-oxidative Direct Methane Conversion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264599
Liu

The non-oxidative direct methane conversion (NDMC) to more valuable and easily transportable chemicals and fuels has remained a grand challenge due to the intrinsic kinetic and thermodynamic constraints. A recent report by the US Energy Information Administration envisions inexpensive and abundant natural gas as a raw material that can significantly impact the chemical and energy supplies of the world. A membrane reactor composed of a metal/zeolite (Mo/ZSM5) catalyst and a hydrogen (H2) permeable membrane has the potential to overcome these kinetic and thermodynamic barriers. The essential feature of the membrane reactor is that Mo species within spatially constrained ZSM5 channels containing Broensted acid sites activate methane to form carbon chains while concurrently restricting the carbon chain length; the H2 permeable membrane continuously removes H2 product to increase conversion relative to feed equilibrium limitations. The key objective of this research is to fabricate and describe novel tubular membrane reactors composed of ZSM5 lamellar catalysts and thin H2 permeable ceramic membranes. A focus of the research is controlling the ZSM5 crystal size by assembly of ZSM5 nanosheets and ceramic membranes to optimize methane (CH4) reaction kinetics and H2 separation in NDMC. Preliminary data show that activity of Mo/ZSM5 and H2 permeation through the ceramic membrane depends strongly on the ZSM5 crystal size and membrane thickness, respectively. A cross-disciplinary strategy will be used to control NDMC and create new and potentially transformative ways of converting reactant methane gas to high value-added fuels and chemicals.

Broader Impacts: The development of efficient NDMC membrane reactors may lead to new thermochemical processes to meet the demand for high-energy density fuels from methane gas. The project integrates research on zeolite chemistry, solid state ioincs, chemical catalysis, and separation processes with an education and outreach component designed to highlight the importance of chemical engineering relevant to energy conversion. Education will be enhanced by developing a new course based upon PIs' research interests in materials, catalysis, separation, and energy, by recruiting and mentoring undergraduate students from underrepresented communities in research activities, and by outreach programs for K-12 students near the University of Maryland.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The depletion and wildly fluctuating prices in crude oil are shifting the market attention to natural gas that is still of great abundance. Methane (CH4), which is the main constituent of natural gas, is deemed to be an alternative source to replace crude oil for the production of value-added chemicals and fuel. Despite its abundance, about 1/3 of the world proven reserves of natural gas (equivalent to 62.4 trillion m3 or 2200 quads of energy) is stranded. The stranded natural gas resources, including those offshore, are too remote from market, and therefore physically unattainable or economically unviable.

This NSF-funded project aims to develop transformative science and modular membrane reactor technology to convert the stranded natural gas into value added C2+ products, and in so doing, increase US economic and energy security while simultaneously decreasing a major source of energy related emissions. In this project, we made breakthroughs in hydrogen (H2) permeable ceramic membrane and direct non-oxidative CH4 conversion (NMC) catalyst technologies. In particular, we have developed a separative/reactive membrane reactor, comprised of a thin dense ambipolar H2 permeable membrane and a NMC catalyst to enabling CH4 conversion into value-added C2+ while solving three major technical challenges, low conversion, low desired product selectivity and inadequate heat supply to drive the high temperature endothermic upgrading reaction. In addition, we carried out the durability and lifetime tests of both membrane and catalyst in the membrane reactor under CH4 feed and a variety of sweep gas compositions. Lastly, we have integrate the science and technology generated from this project into education, including the training for graduate, undergraduate and high school students in the disciplinary of chemical engineering, catalysis, separation and nanomaterials.

Stranded, vented, and flared CH4 represent an enormous loss of economic opportunity as well as environmental damage. Our modular membrane reactor will circumvent thermodynamic limitations in NMC by removal of H2 product in-situ, resulting in increased product yields and energy efficiency, and create economically viable solution for one-step direct non-oxidative natural gas upgrading.


Last Modified: 10/29/2018
Modified by: Dongxia Liu

    Dongxia Liu

    Membrane reactor for methane upgrading
